ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Future opportunities in the Navy, how to be a good officer, etc

I learned a lot from guest speakers and from the insights of the officers in break-out groups. We covered some basic GMTsactive shooter response, proper handling of personal or classified materials, SAPR, etc. We also heard from a variety of guest speakers on topics such as integration of submarines, cybersecurity, etc. Sometimes we would go over scenarios and get feedback from the officers based on their experiences in the fleet. I am grateful for the opportunity to have been able to enroll in the labI feel I have a really solid foundation from NROTC courses and the supplement of this lab for all the miscellaneous things to now be starting in earnest in the fleet.

Learned more about how the Navy works and operates in general, and how Navy higher-ups think through guest lecturers. Had GMTs to talk about proper conduct in the Navy, as well as ethical scenarios to deal with moments of integrity and ethics in the Navy.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was always much too long. There was a planned activity that went well, but the ending announcements were reiterated millions of times will little variation, and this part could be cut out.

I really enjoyed lab and actually looked forward to it, though to be fair that's easy to say when it's not a requirement. I always learned something, and I'm excited now to use what I've learned starting off with the Navy in earnest. I know my place in lab was a bit unorthodox, and I appreciated being included in a squad and in the senior break-out room and the flexibility of the unit to allow me to attend.

My one comment for improvement is that I did do 100% of the reading, and I looked over all the materials carefully; especially for the longer documents, I would have been excited to have a discussion about them and ask questions of the officers, not go over the key points again in a lecture format. The documents covered the key pointsthey provided neat summaries in bullets of the key points at the end of each chapter and an executive summary at the beginning, and a conclusion. If the expectation for lab is that we would read the documents in their entirety, we covered the key points neatly summarized at least three times before lab even started. It would have been great to spend lab time to hear the insights from the officers from their experiences in the fleet; I respectfully submit that this would be a better use of the time we have with the officers. I must also admit that it's a bit disappointing to come prepared and excited to talk about all the content covered and then not have a discussion on the material.
More hands-on and engaging activities. Perhaps more physical activity too.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought we were very productive and learned a lot over lab. It was very well organized! We also had the opportunity to hear from some great speakers remotely.
Live lecture over Zoom was the best we could do under Yale's COVID guidelines.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Well, it's required for the midshipmen. For my part I thought it was helpful and interesting, and I am excited about everything I learned! It's also a great opportunity to get insight from several officers on topics that otherwise would not be covered in their respective classes.
Yes, if you are interested in the Navy.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: It was a meeting held over Zoom and in person at the very end of the semester
This could be a virtual seminar if we divided into break-out rooms or a virtual lecture if we were going through a powerpoint as a main group.
At the beginning of the semester, it was live virtual lecture over Zoom, but our last Lab was in-person in Sudler Hall  in WLH as usual.
